# Academic AI Tools: Questions and Answers

## Infrastructure & Implementation

### Q: How can AI tools be used in journal preparation?
The discussion emphasizes AI as an augmentation tool rather than an automation solution. As stated in the transcript:

> "These tools are very, very, very bad at automation... These things are awful at automation because they do not exhibit judgment. But they can augment and increase the quality of our outputs."

The key applications include:
- Pre-review quality assessment
- Copy editing assistance
- Argument structure analysis
- Initial quality screening

The speaker notes that while this may not increase efficiency, it can improve quality:
> "Note, this is not actually a claim for efficiency. Because doing this is not likely more efficient than skimming the thing and just doing a vibe-based rejector. I do think that this can improve the quality without undue extra time."

### Q: What are the implications for journals tied to major publishers?
The discussion acknowledges the reality of publisher relationships while suggesting preparation for alternatives:

> "We're expecting to be aligned with Springer for the foreseeable future, but certainly some thinking and planning for a potential future where the JBI sits somewhere elsewhere is reasonable and timely."

The speaker presents alternative infrastructure options:
> "This is what allows the Archipelago's journal to be diamond open access. So no fees to libraries, no fees to authors. It's just labor of love posted on GitHub."

### Q: What would be the next steps for a small team with limited technical literacy?
The response emphasizes that technical expertise isn't necessary:

> "This requires no technical knowledge... LLMs are deeply, inherently textual, and they're reliant on text in a way that is directly linked to the skills and methods that we emphasize in university humanities classes."

The key recommendation is developing a "grimoire" (collection of prompts):
> "For you to use this as a journal, the only thing you need to do is have a grimoire... Literally, spell work. That prompts are portable. That if you can encode your tacit expertise into a prompt, you can reuse it."

### Q: How can journals implement AI tools while maintaining quality?
The emphasis is on consent and transparency:
